title: 113_hr3410
content: The Act titled "Critical Infrastructure Protection Act" or "CIPA" defines EMP as electromagnetic pulse caused by intentional or natural means and includes provisions for national planning scenarios and education. The Act "Critical Infrastructure Protection Act" includes provisions for national planning scenarios and education on EMP events, as well as conducting outreach to educate critical infrastructure owners, emergency planners, and responders on the threat of EMP events. Additionally, it includes a section on EMP research and development. The Act "Critical Infrastructure Protection Act" mandates research and development to mitigate the consequences of EMP events, including analyzing risks to critical infrastructures, identifying assets at risk, and evaluating emergency planning technologies. The Critical Infrastructure Protection Act mandates research and development to address the recommendations of experts, including protecting critical infrastructure from EMP attacks and improving restoration capabilities. It also requires a recommended strategy to protect and prepare the American homeland's critical infrastructure. The recommended strategy for protecting the critical infrastructure of the American homeland against EMP events includes biennial updates and consultation with relevant agencies and councils. The Secretary has the authority to incorporate a classified annex if necessary. The Secretary may incorporate the recommended strategy into a broader Department recommendation to protect critical infrastructure from terrorism and other threats. The Secretary may incorporate the recommended strategy into a broader Department recommendation to protect critical infrastructure from terrorism and other threats, including National planning scenarios and education. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a recommended strategy within one year of the enactment of the Act regarding EMP research and development. A report outlining progress and completion estimates for including EMP threats in national planning scenarios, research and development, comprehensive plan development, and outreach to critical infrastructure operators must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Outreach to educate owners and operators of critical infrastructure, emergency planners, and responders at all government levels about the threat of EMP events. The Act passed on December 1, 2014, states that it does not grant any regulatory authority and can only be implemented using funds appropriated under other laws.
